content:
How did this get validated? The default stub only provides one line and not all the input, and games on CodinGame always specify the amount of incoming lines so that languages that don't have a while(read()) like function can still work.
The "ends when 0" is not the way to do it.

This is a good question, but input management by the default code really needs a rework
The provided solution is wrong on at least one testcase !

The stub generator can not be correct due to this "read until 0" method. And also the input "0" must not be considered as a "good" number even if it's written "All single digit numbers are considered "Good"."

It's a good clash. The text is easy to understand, tests and validators are ok (I find the same results). I'm just not a fan of the word "good" (specially for the title) but I have no better words !
I'd like to see the amount of numbers that i have to read from stdin as first input

Read until 0 as alternative to read count before data is acceptable, even if unusual by codingame standards. Might even be seen as a breath of fresh air ;) Especially for golfing purposes - so you can add shortest mode to it.

Thought it's self explanatory that 0 shouldn't be taken into account, Look at Validator 4 and Test 5, it says NONE because there are no "Good" numbers found, hence the 0 is not taken into account.

However, if more people consider this a problem, I will add a note to the statement.

I honestly don't know what you're talking about as I personally tested it multiple times and it's passing everything.

P.S. The solution which was wrong was posted AND FIXED 15 minutes after I posted this puzzle. The reason it was wrong was because I originally had a different statement and I wrote a solution for that, since the statement changed I also changed the solution.

I used the solution to make test cases. random.org for numbers and then my solution for the results. It couldn't have been wrong..

UPDATE: I was just suggested by a fellow CGer that I might have updated the solution but  forgot to save it. It's possible that this had happened, therefore the solution from the first statement was still there.

The reason in only has 1 line is the fact that it's a bad one as it doesn't support loops except the most basic one, repeat N times.

Why wouldn't we be able to handle unknown amount of numbers? Realistically speaking, you don't always know how many cases you need to work with. Take any real life situation, you don't always know how many things you need to do, but you know when you need to stop

It obviously got validated because not everyone wants all the puzzles to be the same. Delete it, edit it, i don't mind. I can see many people agreeing with me, else it wouldn't get such a positive rating and get validated less than 2 days after being submitted.

I don't see your point, If you give N = the amount of numbers, then a for(0..N) loop that parses inputs, you still allow N to change with each test case. And I'm pretty sure the reason we do this with most puzzle is that there are language that don't support the "while(STDIN-is-not-empty)" thing.
I'll look into this and if it is indeed the case, I will have to edit it. The question is fine as is, I personally don't mind doing extra work parsing inputs, but it still feels odd that the default stub doesn't give all inputs. I would rather have it give nothing and say "parse inputs by yourself", than just give one line

Hum... very strange, you solution printed "0" instead of "NONE" for testcase 7 but it seems OK now ...

Ok you just update your solution at 9:28 utc...
Updated the previous comment.
I think that the submission form even allows such situation is entirely [CG] fault and not the submitter's :p
i agree, will be fixed very soon!
Just put the number of values on the first line to be coherent with all other puzzles!
I don't mind, but why have every puzzle the same? I know it's not a big difference, but still..

Mainly because otherwise you can not write a working stub generator!
And for a clash, it's better to have some coherence between each question to not force to have to make an effort of understanding when the time is counted.

Absolutely agree with this opinion. Took me 12 minutes to solve this, 10 of which trying to understand how on earth did this get approved in the first place. Definitely a 5 minute task merits to do something that is entirely different than all other 2000 puzzles and CoCs on the site. It's an especially nice surprise when you are actually solving it in fastest mode so you have to scan through the task fast and work with whatever is in the IDE, which not even resembles the actual input... Huge disappointment.

I agree with you 100%, I won't edit the puzzle (although I REALLY WANT TO) 'cause it's 4 years old and I don't want to change CG history or something... But yeah, it took me over 80% of the time trying to get through the anger of this being the only puzzle with this syntax probably on the site...
It is not acceptable for a functional programming style. Imperatively it's easy to deal with, but it adds a shitload of unnecessary boilerplate in haskell.
takeWhile?

Its type is (a -> Bool) -> [a] -> [a] where the type i would be looking for is Monad m => (a -> Bool) -> m a -> m a.

A close match would be
liftM (takeWhile (/="0") <$> replicateM _ getLine

the problem lies in that i still don't know the value at the underscore.

sequence (repeat getLine) would cause issues because of lazy evaluation.

infinite values inside the monad are just a pain to deal with
